nexttext:
where $\zeta$ is a normalization parameter introduced in \cite{Cherman:2008eh}.

According to Gell-Mann-Oakes-Renner (GOR) relationship, $m_{q}$ and $\sigma$ are related by  $m_{\pi}^{2} f_{\pi}^{2} = 2 m_{q} \sigma$, and if we expand (\ref{vevSW}) to small values of holographic coordinate, we get $\alpha \sim m_{q}$ and $\beta \sim \sigma \sim m_{q}$, and this means in this model when quark mass is zero then the chiral condensate is also zero, and this is not in agreement to GOR.

In the literature there are some alternatives to solve this problem. For example, a negative quadratic dilaton could be a possible alternative \cite{Zuo:2009dz}, but it predicts an extra massless mode that are not observed \cite{Karch:2010eg}. Recently it was suggested \cite{Chelabi:2015cwn}
 that an interpolation between two quadratic dilatons, one negative to small z and another positive to high z, could solve the problem without spurious modes that appear with only a negative dilaton.

Another way to improve this model is to consider adding a quartic term in scalar potential together with a dilaton that interpolates between two limits obtained from functions that reproduce the vev in a good way \cite{Gherghetta:2009ac}.

In both cases, dilaton satisfies

prevtext:
where $\zeta$ is a normalization parameter introduced in \cite{Cherman:2008eh}.

According to Gell-Mann-Oakes-Renner (GOR) relationship, $m_{q}$ and $\sigma$ are related by  $m_{\pi}^{2} f_{\pi}^{2} = 2 m_{q} \sigma$, and if we expand (\ref{vevSW}) to small values of holographic coordinate, we get $\alpha \sim m_{q}$ and $\beta \sim \sigma \sim m_{q}$, and this means in this model when quark mass is zero then the chiral condensate is also zero, and this is not in agreement to GOR.

In the literature there are some alternatives to solve this problem. For example, a negative quadratic dilaton could be a possible alternative \cite{Zuo:2009dz}, but it predicts an extra massless mode that are not observed \cite{Karch:2010eg}. Recently it was suggested \cite{Chelabi:2015cwn}
 that an interpolation between two quadratic dilatons, one negative to small z and another positive to high z, could solve the problem without spurious modes that appear with only a negative dilaton.

Another way to improve this model is to consider adding a quartic term in scalar potential together with a dilaton that interpolates between two limits obtained from functions that reproduce the vev in a good way \cite{Gherghetta:2009ac}.

In both cases, dilaton satisfies

nexttext:
where $\kappa_{0}^{2} = - \kappa_{\infty}^{2}$ in \cite{Chelabi:2015cwn} and $\kappa_{0}^{2} \neq \kappa_{\infty}^{2}$ in \cite{Gherghetta:2009ac}. We notice that, without details, which dilatons corresponding to interpolations between limit (\ref{ExtremosGherghetta1}) and (\ref{ExtremosGherghetta2}) according to some authors can improve other facts in the SW model (to the interested reader we suggest as example \cite{Li:2013oda}).

Dilatons with this behavior cannot be obtained from (\ref{EcuacionFamiliaDilaton}), because the original potential and the strictly isospectral potential are equal to low and high z values, i.e. for dilatons of family found $\phi (z \rightarrow 0) = \phi (z \rightarrow \infty) = \kappa^{2} z^{2}$. However, it is possible to introduce small changes (\ref{EcuacionFamiliaDilaton}) in order to get dilatons in agreement with (\ref{ExtremosGherghetta1}) and (\ref{ExtremosGherghetta2}). To achieve this, we added a new term in (\ref{EcuacionFamiliaDilaton}) that slightly modifies the behavior at small z.

So we have two possible alternatives to introduce the change, on the right or left side in (\ref{EcuacionFamiliaDilaton}). Ergo, instead of (\ref{EcuacionFamiliaDilaton}) we suggest:

where $\delta$ and $p$ are two parameters that modify the behavior of $\phi(z)$ at low $z$.

\begin{figure}[b]
\label{fig:Npositivo}
\includegraphics[width=3.3 in]{Fig3.pdf}
\caption{Dilatons for different values of $\delta$, $p=even$, $\kappa = 428~[MeV]$, $m_{5}=0$ and $\lambda=0.1$}
\end{figure}

In Figures (3) and (4) it is possible to see how $\delta$ modifies the magnitude of $\phi(z \rightarrow 0)$, and by using even or odd p values was possible to choose the sign of $\phi(0)$ according to (\ref{ModificacionIzquierda}) or (\ref{ModificacionDerecha}). Increasing $\delta$ produces differences between the  spectrum calculated with quadratic dilaton and the one obtained from (\ref{ModificacionIzquierda}), (\ref{ModificacionDerecha}) or (\ref{Modificacion}). This constrains us to use small values for $\delta$ if we wish a dilaton which produce spectra very close to the original one.

The behavior of the dilaton obtained in both extensions is $\phi \rightarrow C \pm \kappa_{0}^2 z^2$, with $C$ a const.

It is worth noting in relation to implementation of chiral symmetry breaking in AdS / QCD models that the constant term is not important, and it can be dropped to calculate other quantities. And if the change suggested it was implemented  according to (\ref{ModificacionIzquierda}) or (\ref{ModificacionDerecha}) determines if is $\kappa_{0} < \kappa_{\infty}$ or $\kappa_{0} > \kappa_{\infty}$.







\section{Summary and conclusions}

In this work we showed that use of techniques that allow strictly isospectral potentials in Schr\"odinger-like equations offer a possibility to of introducing improvements in SW models. In particular, we used transformations taken from SUSY QM to get families of strictly isospectral potentials, and from this we showed how it is possible to obtain families of metrics and / or dilatons. This paper focused on familes of dilatons considering the AdS metric to study scalar glueballs. The procedure discussed throughout this paper could be interesting in the search for alternatives for quadratic dilatons commonly used with AdS metric.

As we mentioned, the ideas exposed in this work were implemented by considering a Schr\"odinger-type equation used to describe scalar hadrons in SW models. In particular, we considered scalar glueballs to explain how to get a family of dilatons for SW models with an AdS metric in an easy case. Dilatons obtained in this way, we think, can be used to improve some facts in AdS / QCD models.

The procedure presented produce dilatons according to $\phi (z \rightarrow 0) = \kappa_{0}^{2} z^{2}$ and $\phi (z \rightarrow \infty) = \kappa_{\infty}^{2} z^{2}$ where $\kappa_{0} = \kappa_{\infty}$. These kinds of dilatons are not good for models that try to implement chiral symmetry breaking, but by introducing small changes in procedure we could obtain dilatons with $\kappa_{0} \neq \kappa_{\infty}$, which according to \cite{Chelabi:2015cwn, Gherghetta:2009ac}, it provides an opportunity to improve this kind of models.

In this first work we have shown that it is possible introduce improvements in AdS / QCD models that consider chiral symmetry breaking building a family of dilatons by using SUSY QM techniques. And we believe it would be interesting to study the effect of this kind of changes in other quantities calculated in SW models. Additionally, it could be beneficial to use this procedure for to obtain a family of metrics. These considerations will be explored by us in a future work.

\label{fig:Nnegativo}

\caption{Dilatons for different values of $\delta$, $p=odd$, $\kappa = 428~[MeV]$, $m_{5}=0$ and $\lambda=0.1$ }
\end{figure}
